resources.string:
The purpose of the game is to decline the adjective of the given german sentences, according to gender, number and case of the noun and the type of declination (definite articles, undefinite articles, null articles), see the cheatsheet page for more information about adjective declension.
 
 The gender (or number) of the noun is given in brackets at the end of the sentence:
 m = masculine
 f = feminine
 n = neutral
 p = plural.
 
 For the definite and indefinite articles declension, this information together with the article is enough to derive the case (nominative, accusative, dative or genitive) and decline the adjective.
 
 For the last case (null article), the case is given (in brackets at the end of the sentence) because it cannot be derived:
 n = nominative
 a = accusative
 d = dative
 g = genitive.

e.g.: das gute Kind
 
 also with demonstrative articles, interrogative particles and some distributives:
 
 definite articles: der, die, das, den, .. 
 
 demonstrative articles: dieser, dieses, diese, jener, jenes, jene, derselbe, dasselbe, dieselbe, .. 
 
 interrogative particles: welcher, welches, welche, .. 
 
 distributives: jeder, jedes, jede, ..

e.g.: ein gutes Kind
 
 also with negation articles, possessive articles:
 
 indefinite articles: ein, eine, einen, .. 
 
 negation articles: kein, keine, .. 
 
 possessive articles: mein, meine, .. 
 
 distributives: jeder, jedes, jede, ..

e.g.: alter Mann
 
 also with digits, some distributives, relative pronomes:
 
 digits: 1, 2, 3, .. 
 
 distributives (plural): einige, viele, wenige, etliche, andere, manche, .. 
 
 distributives (singular): viel, mehr, wenig, .. 
 
 relative pronomes (genitiv): dessen, deren, ..
